comment_data.body:
So, if I'm understanding this correctly, you're proposing adding an IDE feature that enables creating a code fragment template of one parameter as well as a marker that indicates where the cursor should end up.  We'd use this feature to create a bunch of useful templates, like the three outlined in this issue's description. Is that right?

I do have some thoughts about functionality and usability; wanted to make sure I understood the proposal first though.

That's about right, I think. We'll use the existing IDE template creation mechanism to pre-populate some Flutter-specific templates. The $SELECTION$ and $END$ variables are magic, and work as you describe. You can create additional variables so we might define more variables for more complex templates. The values for the additional variables would be filled-in after the template had been expanded.

My question is whether pre-defined templates will be useful enough to justify adding them to the plugin. I'll be happy to answer any additional questions you have.

I think this could be a useful feature, particularly for new developers.  It doesn't address two of the use cases mentioned at the outset:
- Make this stateless widget stateful
- Add an AnimationController to this stateful widget
- And I suppose since this is a wish after all, moving a new widget expression from stateful back to stateless, etc.

That said, there's plenty of utility in providing the standard boilerplate for common 'new widget expressions'.  

Inserting an expanded template seems a little clunky:

>  ...typing the name of the new class, selecting it, then selecting the template from the menu (Cmd-Opt-J on Mac or Cmd-Opt-T on Mac). 

It's not clear where the name would go, it seems like temporary text that you'd delete after the template was selected/expanded? The whole process might be more intuitive and informative if you gave the user a dialog with a brief explanation of what the template was for and fields for the template variables (the stateful widget with an animation controller template could have variables for both the class name and the animation controller variable name). 

Similarly a template dialog might enable making an informed decision about selecting a different template. For example: the user selects the basic 'new stateless widget' template which says: if the widget's layout is to be animated, then use the 'new Animated widget' template instead. Clicking that would switch templates and help educate developers about the options.

If wishes were horses.

Here's a short movie showing two of the three requested templates in action:
[template_demo.zip](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/files/845444/template_demo.zip)
To keep file size down I only recorded a small part of the IntelliJ editing pane. I used Cmd-Shift-RightArrow to select the word and Cmd-Opt-J to bring up the menu.

If you think this would be useful we'd probably just add some of these templates to the next release. They are quite easy to define.

Creating a tool to automatically convert stateless to state-full, or add an animation controller, is a lot more work. The conversions would probably be useful to more people, though. As you indicate, using the IntelliJ "assist" (Alt-Newline) feature to implement the conversion may not be optimal. Defining a new refactoring operation would allow displaying a form where various bits could be filled in. It would be a lot more discoverable if we add something to the `Refactor` menu.

/cc @pq

I uploaded the video to YouTube because Linux: https://youtu.be/6Yan2pNSwU0

What you've got looks pretty useful and I'm sure we could define quite a few templates this way.  Making the templates easy to discover and configure would be really helpful.

Awesome!  I especially like how this mechanism allows folks to define their own templates for their own widgets (and other boilerplate).  The discoverability problem is a tough one but since this is so low cost, I'm up for exploring it and seeing if, with training/docs, we can get folks on the happy path to using them.

With PR https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/pull/834 there are now three templates defined to generate the boilerplate shown above. The templates are named: stless, stful, stanim.

To generate a new StatefulWidget, for example, you would type `stful` then `tab`, then type the name of the class once. That name will be inserted everywhere it needs to be in the expanded text.

To see all the available IntelliJ templates, open Preferences/Settings and navigate to Editor > Live Templates. We're taking requests for more templates. :) And we're tying to find better ways to publicize them.

We're still thinking about how to convert a widget from one type to another.
Thanks! Should we open a documentation issue so we mention this new capability in our website docs?

For clarity, we've done the work to address widget creation, with the boilerplate templates. We have not yet done any work on a refactoring tool that would convert one kind of widget to another. That would involve determining which parts of the boilerplate are present and which absent and then generating new source to add/remove parts as needed, without breaking anything.
We [implemented](https://dart-review.googlesource.com/c/sdk/+/39921) a Quick Assist (activated using Alt+Enter) to convert `StatelessWidget` to `StatefulWidget`.

milestone.description: Work triaged but not yet planned for a specific release.
milestone.title: Backlog

title: Flutter IDE Wish: Define a Stateful/Stateless widget class
